articles.headline: Extremism Rises Among Myanmar Buddhists
articles.snippet: Amid hate-filled speeches and violence, a nationwide fundamentalist movement has grown with an agenda that now includes boycotts of Muslim-made goods.
articles.abstract: Amid hate-filled speeches and violence, a nationwide fundamentalist movement has grown with an agenda that now includes boycotts of Muslim-made goods.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAUNGGYI, Myanmar — After a ritual prayer atoning for past sins, Ashin Wirathu, a Buddhist monk with a rock-star following in Myanmar, sat before an overflowing crowd of thousands of devotees and launched into a rant against what he called “the enemy” — the country’s Muslim minority.

articles.headline: Facebook Takes On Twitter With Video
articles.snippet: The company will add an instant 15-second video service to Instagram, in an answer to Twitter’s Vine feature.
articles.abstract: The company will add an instant 15-second video service to Instagram, in an answer to Twitter’s Vine feature.
articles.lead_paragraph: MENLO PARK, Calif. — If “60 Minutes” were being dreamed up today, its producers might very well have ditched the idea and gone with “6 Seconds” instead.
articles.byline: By Vindu Goel and Jenna Wortham

articles.headline: Tribune Falls Afoul of Its Own Tax Strategy
articles.snippet: The media company, just out of bankruptcy, is now facing millions of dollars in taxes and penalties.
articles.abstract: The media company, just out of bankruptcy, is now facing millions of dollars in taxes and penalties.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was perhaps the cleverest corporate tax strategy ever devised: no matter how much money the company made, neither it nor its shareholders would ever owe a penny in federal income taxes.

articles.headline: When a Founder Is the Face of a Brand
articles.snippet: Tying an executive’s personality to his or her business can be highly successful until the executive ages, leaves, dies or gets into trouble.
articles.abstract: Tying an executive’s personality to his or her business can be highly successful until the executive ages, leaves, dies or gets into trouble.
articles.lead_paragraph: Companies can fire a founder.  But they can’t fire his brand.

articles.headline: Marijuana Crops in California Threaten Forests and Wildlife
articles.snippet: California growers are acknowledging that like logging before it, their booming business is a threat to forests whose giant redwoods preside over vibrant ecosystems.
articles.abstract: California growers are acknowledging that like logging before it, their booming business is a threat to forests whose giant redwoods preside over vibrant ecosystems.
articles.lead_paragraph: ARCATA, Calif. — It took the death of a small, rare member of the weasel family to focus the attention of Northern California’s marijuana growers on the impact that their huge and expanding activities were having on the environment.

articles.headline: Two Economies in Turmoil, for Different Reasons
articles.snippet: Fed officials are convinced they have done enough stimulus, but some critics see evidence in the persistence of high unemployment and low inflation that the Fed should do even more.
articles.abstract: Fed officials are convinced they have done enough stimulus, but some critics see evidence in the persistence of high unemployment and low inflation that the Fed should do even more.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, meant to deliver two dollops of good news on Wednesday: the economy is doing better, and the Fed is determined to keep it that way. He announced that the Fed would extend one part of its stimulus campaign, suggested that it might extend another part, and offered new details about the timing.

articles.headline: Global Sell-off Shows Fed Reach Beyond the U.S.
articles.snippet: Tumbling stock, bond and commodity prices around the world in recent weeks are demonstrating just how reliant the global economy has become on the policies of the Federal Reserve.
articles.abstract: Tumbling stock, bond and commodity prices around the world in recent weeks are demonstrating just how reliant the global economy has become on the policies of the Federal Reserve.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tumbling stock, bond and commodity prices around the world are demonstrating just how reliant the global economy has become on the monetary policies of the Federal Reserve.

articles.headline: Negotiations With Taliban Could Hinge on Detainees
articles.snippet: Five prisoners at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, could be the key to whether the talks the United States has long sought with the Taliban are a success.
articles.abstract: Five prisoners at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, could be the key to whether the talks the United States has long sought with the Taliban are a success.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two were senior Taliban commanders said to be implicated in murdering thousands of Shiites in Afghanistan. When asked about the alleged war crimes by an interrogator, they “did not express any regret and stated they did what they needed to do in their struggle to establish their ideal state,” according to their interrogators.

articles.headline: Global Sell-Off Shows Fed Reach Beyond the U.S.
articles.snippet: Markets calmed down on Friday, but tumbling stock, bond and commodity prices around the world have shown how reliant the global economy has become on the policies of the Federal Reserve.
articles.abstract: Markets calmed down on Friday, but tumbling stock, bond and commodity prices around the world have shown how reliant the global economy has become on the policies of the Federal Reserve.
articles.lead_paragraph: Despite a partial recovery in the markets on Friday, tumbling stock, bond and commodity prices around the world over the past month are demonstrating just how reliant the global economy has become on the monetary policies of the Federal Reserve.

articles.headline: China’s Credit Squeeze Relaxes as Interest Rates Drop
articles.snippet: Tight credit eased Friday, but financial markets remained under pressure as Beijing seemed to be tackling poor lending practices.
articles.abstract: Tight credit eased Friday, but financial markets remained under pressure as Beijing seemed to be tackling poor lending practices.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China’s credit squeeze eased Friday after lending resumed among banks and financial institutions that had been desperately seeking cash through the week in the interbank market.
